document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic note on the oil-collecting bee Centris dimidiata (Olivier, 1789) (Hymenoptera: Apidae: Centridini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic note on the oil-collecting bee Centris dimidiata (Olivier, 1789) (Hymenoptera: Apidae: Centridini)

heading.emphasis:
Centris ( Melacentris ) atriventris Mocsáry, 1896
nom. rev.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Female: Mesoscutum, mesoscutellum and anterior surface of tegula with orange hairs with dark orange tips. Mandible with four teeth (1st>3rd>4th>2nd): first and second with acute apex, third rounded and fourth truncate. Basitibial plates elliptical, posterior margin of secondary plate projected backwards ( Fig. 9 ). Male: Clypeus with two brown spots on upper half ( Fig. 2 ). Dorsal surface of mesosoma and tegula with orange hairs with dark orange tips ( Fig. 6 ). Metepisternum and propodeum with light brown pubescence. Base of hind claw with tuft of branched hairs on each side ( Fig. 15 ). Mandible with three teeth (3rd>1st>2nd) of acute apex, except third concave. This species is most similar to
C . furcata
. Females of both species differ by the width of their mandibular teeth (1st>3rd>4th>2nd in
C . atriventris
, 1st>2nd>4th>3rd in
C . furcata
, Fig. 3 ), by the coloration of their clypeus (orange brown in
C . atriventris
, dark brown in
C . furcata
) and by the shape of their secondary basitibial plate (projected backwards in
C . atriventris
, Fig. 9 ; not projected backwards in
C . furcata
, Fig. 10 ). Males differ mainly by the size of their second and third mandibular teeth (3rd>2nd in
C . atriventris
, Fig. 13 ; 2nd>3rd in
C . furcata
Fig. 14 ) and by the tuft of branched hairs at the base of the hind pretarsal claws (present in
C . atriventris
, Fig. 15 ; absent in
C . furcata
, Fig. 16 ).

Male ( Figs. 2 , 6 , 13, 15 ). Description: Measurements: Approximate body length: 27.0; head width: 7.3; thorax width: 9.3; forewing length: 18.8; UID: 2.5; LID: 3.0; mandible length: 3.2; mandible basal width: 1.5; F1 length: 0.9; F2 length: 0.4; F3 length: 0.5. Coloration: Frons, vertex, mandible, mesosoma, legs, and metasoma dark brown to black ( Figs. 2 , 6 , 13 ). Lower paraocular area, clypeus, labrum and anterior surface of scape yellow ( Figs. 2 , 13 ). Tegula yellowish brown ( Fig. 6 ). Wing membrane and veins dark brown ( Fig. 6 ) with green/violet iridescence. Sculpture: Clypeus conspicuously areolate with relatively fine and dense punctation, slightly coarser laterally (di<ds). Labrum with relatively thin, dense and uniform punctation (di>ds), with well-defined smooth basal surface margin. T1 with fine and relatively dense punctures (di≈ds). T2 and T3 with finer and denser punctation than on T1 (di>ds). T4–T6 with slightly coarse and dense punctures (di>ds). Pubescence: Head, legs and metasoma with dark brown to black hairs ( Fig. 6 ). Coxae and trochanters with yellowish brown pubescence. Mesepisternum mainly with yellow pilosity, slightly darker under wings ( Fig. 6 ). Pronotal lobe with yellowish hairs with orange tips ( Fig. 6 ). T1‒T3 with dense pilosity. T4–T6 with branched hairs. Ventral surface of mid tarsi of hind leg with yellow, long, curved hairs. Ventral surface of hind distitarsus with brown hairs not forming a comb. Structures: Flabellum elliptical with slightly narrow anterior margin. Mandible strongly curved apically ( Figs. 2 , 13 ). Acetabular carina reaching base of third tooth ( Figs. 2 , 13 ). Trimal angle not well-developed, acute ( Fig. 13 ). Maxillary palpus with three palpomeres (2nd≈3rd>1st). Clypeus with upper half slightly convex, lower half slightly concave (lateral view). Labrum relatively triangular ( Figs. 2 , 13 ). Vertex above upper interocular tangent ( Fig. 2 ).

Variation . Female clypeus uniformly convex to slightly concave on lower half; mesoscutum and mesoscutellum with hairs slightly yellowish to orange with dark orange tips; sterna with integument dark to light brown. Male with supraclypeal area dark brown to yellow ( Fig. 2 ); mesosoma with light orange or slightly yellowish pubescence.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–4. Figs. 1 and 2.
Centris atriventris Mocsáry, 1896
. Fig. 1. Female (Brazil: Tefé): Head, frontal view (scale bar 1 mm). Fig. 2. Male (Brazil: Camanaus): Head, frontal view (scale bar 1 mm). Figs. 3 and 4.
C . furcata (Fabricius, 1804)
. Fig. 3. Female (Brazil: Óbidos): Head, frontal view (scale bar 1 mm). Fig. 4. Male (Brazil: Tapuruquara): Head, frontal view (scale bar 1 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph: Type data. Syntypes: three females and one male (HNHM). A syntype female with the following information: “631 159\ Teffé Brasilia” and with an additional yellow square label on it is here designated as lectotype ( Fig. 21 ). According to the accession book at HNHM this specimen was purchased through the insect dealer Otto Staudinger in 1882.
Original type localities. Brazil: Tefé, São Paulo, “Massanary”. Lectotype locality: Brazil: Amazonas: Tefé.

Comment. A female collected in the Brazilian state of Espírito Santo was found in DZUP with the following information: “Sta. Teresa-ES Brasil 23-III-54 C. Elias leg”. This record needs to be confirmed because it is far away from the distribution range of this species (see Fig. 25 ).
